Because have the syntactic form of an argument list, there is an inherent ambiguity in the representation of a nil . Consider the macro the following macro definitions and invocations:
#define A() #define B(x)
A() B(1)
The A macro is defined as nullary, while the B macro is defined as unary. When A is invoked, it is invoked with the first of two forms of nil used by the library--nullary parentheses, (). When B is invoked, it is invoked with a that is clearly unary. However, with the introduction of placemarkers in C99, the distinction is no longer clear. For example,
B()
Here, B is invoked with what appears to be, but isn't, a nil . It is invoked with a unary whose only element is empty. (This is why (()) expands to 1 in C99.) Fundamentally, this is no different than a of greater arity with empty elements.
(,,)

Several problems arise from this situation when using as data structures. The first is that there is no general way of detecting the difference between () and (1). It is possible to get fairly close in various ways by restricting the types of elements, but a general solution is impossible.

Even if such detection was possible, another problem surfaces. Consider again the (,,) , and consider an algorithm that operates on each element of a . If the algorithm was to attempt to individually process elements one-by-one, it might use and . Everything is fine for ((,,)) (which yields (,)). However, ((,)) yields () (i.e. the theoretical nil ), and an element has been silently skipped.
The underlying problem is that emptiness (or "nothing") is a useful and perfectly valid form of data in its own right.

As a consequence, algorithms and primitives that operate on algorithmically need to use a distinct representation for nil that has no ambiguity. This representation is () which simply expands to nothing. This model always treats () as a unary , and (()) expands to nothing.

Note that this issue arises only with algorithms and primitives that operate on algorithmically, and can only be operated on algorithmically in C99. Thus, all -specific primitives present in C (prior to C99) and C++ operate on () nil . (For compatibility, these primitives are semantically identical in C99.)

It is sometimes necessary to convert an empty nil to a () nil . One such case is when the is to be directly used as an argument list. This can be accomplished with code such as the following:
((a, b, c)) // (a, b, c) () // ()
However, no conversion in the other direction is possible.
